body:
~~Is this not covered here?: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/288~~

Edit: #288 won't cover the case of env var interpolation in `airflow.cfg` but #361 will.

So the two ways of injecting env vars are:

``` bash
DATABASE_URL=whatever
AIRFLOW__CORE__SQL_ALCHEMY_CONN=$DATABASE_URL
```

OR, in `airflow.cfg`:

```
[core]
sql_alchemy_conn=$DATABASE_URL
```

I think I have one more case where it's challenging and that's interpolating variables that exist within a cfg file. An example would illustrate this better:

```
[core]
airflow_home = /app/user

dags_folder = %(airflow_home)s/dags

base_log_folder = %(airflow_home)s/logs
```

In this example, I'm able to reuse `airflow_home` to define the paths in other places within the config. If that's possible with #361, then I'm happy to close this PR.

Merged here:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/386

Got it -- I know that fully interpolated `ConfigParsers` are available in Python 3 (where you could actually refer to other variables defined in the `.cfg` file) but I don't know about Python 2. 

To recreate the behavior you want, you can use the env var to set the cfg. I think that in your example, you would actually end up with potentially two conflicting airflow_home's (I have an open issue about that #324)

```
[core]
airflow_home = $AIRFLOW_HOME
dags_folder = $AIRFLOW_HOME/dags # note this is dependent on the env var, not the cfg var
base_log_folder = $AIRFLOW_HOME/logs
```
@jlowin Cool with me. Looks like my changes aren't needed. I don't know if this is in the documentation anywhere but I'll see if I can score some time to write that up.
woops -- didn't see the #244 issue where this was mentioned.
Just wanted to save you the effort! I think you're right -- only the #288 piece is documented (http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/installation.html#configuration), not the #361 part.
We could open one for the community, but I can't commit to yet one more communication channel. Plus I'd rather build a knowledge base.

@jlowin, what I realized while reading this thread is that my use cases are all composed of chunks of tasks that _are_ known in advance.  For reference, here are the cases I've seen from myself or others:
- doing the same set of work at a set of timings determined by a remote service
- performing a set of analyses on every file in a folder, row in a database, or component in a social graph

In each of these cases, I know the work I want to do at deployment time, just not exactly when / how many times / on what.  Enumerating those repeated chunks as separate DAGs is actually a great feature, because it lets Airflow align the repeated steps (tasks) across runs for analytics, and perform localized management operations on e.g. all tasks upstream of a certain point within one run of one chunk.

So, my problem is not really with static DAGs but with the fact that they can be only triggered by time.  If I could schedule a DAG run on demand, ideally with a wee bit of metadata so that tasks know what triggered the run, I could have all of the features that depend on the static DAG and still deal with the irregularities in my schedule.

I can't think of a realistic use case where a truly dynamic DAG would be preferable to dynamically triggering static chunks.  Extremely complex workflows might require tons of DAGs triggering each other - but if you find yourself in that situation, maybe you're using a workflow scheduler to do flow control that would be better implemented as program logic?

That sounds right -- I also discovered that most of my "dynamic" DAGs were actually just static DAGs being used repeatedly but at non-regular times. I also learned that Airflow handles "slowly changing" DAGs very well -- where "slowly changing" means adding or removing a task after multiple runs.
Do you have a zombie task instance that is flagged as running but not actually running? Clear it!

I really like the DB table analogy -- it conveys that workflows might change with business needs, but probably shouldn't change during operation-as-usual.  You also have some good language in a few threads about reorienting workflows to, for example, operate on all files rather than doing one task per file.  Also to pick up occasional changes in a workflow by making the script declaring the DAG itself dynamic.  Probably good stuff for that FAQ section!

The catch that led me to this thread is wanting to use Airflow's failure-management features to resume flows that fail during these corner cases.  If the "per-file" work is complex, I don't want a failure on one file to block and require repeating of the whole task.  And if the DAG-generation script would have to pull a schedule off of a failure-prone external service, I don't want Airflow to potentially barf when loading it.  When you(/we?) get dynamic triggering going, I can take care of both kinds of risk by making a task that triggers a separate, pre-declared DAG.  Then a failure in pulling down an external schedule just blocks that triggering task, and a failure in the "per-file" DAG only holds up that run.

(Now I'll officially stop belaboring how excited I am about that feature :) )

Initially my start_date was set to `start_date: datetime.today()` after changing it to as shown above code in my previous comment, the tree got updated to show the status of the tasks. I did the same changes to the dependent job as well and it started to work. Leaving the issue open until someone comments to make sure, if the issue was caused due to `start_date: datetime.today()`

OK. I found the cause.

We run airflow (webserver and scheduler) on one of our EC2 machines called ETL-00. We auto-scale this instance for one of the processes (importers) running on this machine. This machine runs many processes that don't need auto-scaling, such as the airflow webserver and scheduler, so we need to ensure those processes are stopped on the "replicated" auto-scaled instances. It turns out that we were not killing or stopping the airflow scheduler fast enough on those replicas, so the replicas were picking up tasks not meant for them. And, since the user-data would kill the process on the auto-scaled machines, the work was not completing. 

I'm closing this ticket.

1. Criteria for pickling is same as in BackfillJob
2. Since the default behavior had been to not pickle, I made the argument as do_pickle, to explicitly insist on pickling.
3. Can run as airflow scheduler -p to see it in action

If form_columns is used for using only specific fields from the model or for forcing a certain order of fields, form_extra_fields need to be in there as well, otherwise they will be ignored. 

Fixed by #396
Premature close, will close when fix is merged.

`datetime.today()` is a `datetime.date` type, not a `datetime.datetime`, this may create some problems. The docs specify clearly that `start_date` receives a `datetime.datetime`, but I can see how using a date could be a common pitfall. I just added a warning message on start_date's type, it will make the next version

Good catch. I admit it can get tricky to read through what is happening in a distributed environment. I noticed people get tangled, post about it, and it's really hard to help out from outside the environment.

One thing that could help is better event logging from all involved machines / processes. If we logged more events like "scheduler started", "scheduler ended", "web server started", "read msg from queue", along with the hostname, timestamp, environment variables, ... that could really help people people sys admins on a small cluster of Airflow machines.

I think allowing the scheduler to scale out to multiple processes or machines would be very simple. There are already some of the mechanics in place (`DagModel.scheduler_lock`, DagModel.last_scheduler_run).

Now it would be only a matter of taking and releasing the locks in `SchedulerJob`, and have some mechanism to expire the locks.

Without locking in place 2 schedulers could step on each other's toes, though in theory no task instance should ever double trigger since the worker checks and alters the task instance's status as part of a database transaction. So 2 schedulers might send the same message to the queue, but in theory the workers should sort it out (only the first worker to get the message should actually end up running the task).

Right, currently it's consistently server time zone throughout the framework, for us it happens to be UTC.

I get your point though, but I'm not sure on the implications or how easy / complex this would be, and how much change management would be required.

+1 this.  If you look in models.py: is_queueable():
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L642
There's this line: 

```
  if self.execution_date > datetime.now() - self.task.schedule_interval:
            return False
```

This makes sense for hourly or daily jobs - you need to wait for the day to finish to start this.  But if want to have a weekly job that runs at the end of the week - this will wait until 7 days after the end of the week.  

I guess you can get around this by making your schedule based on a start date of the first day of the week...

This is still fairly unmapped territories, so operators or function arguments you might need or best practices have not been defined yet. 

One easy way to leverage more out of the xcom framework would be for `SimpleHttpOperator` to return the response's data, which will create an xcom entry (any operator's execute return value gets "xcommed"). This would become available wherever `SimpleHttpOperator` is used.

It also seems like posting + sensing is a common use case and it's nicer when it's executed atomically as one task instead of 2. So there could be a `HttpPostThenSense` of some kind, or you can do this in a very simple PythonOperator as well.

Now I'm guessing you are interfacing with a specific system that exposes a web API. So say if that system was something called "AmazonBackups", you could write a specific AmazonBackupOperator with the perfect interface for it.

Hi everyone,
Any updates on this issue? This functionality is critical for running tasks in a distributed manner using a non-local executor. For example MesosExecutor (see https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/398 )
Please provide your comments on https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/394 for a proposed patch.
Looks good structurally, adding a few comments inline

Quick note to the effect that the core maintainers of Airflow won't be able to test, grow and fix this feature, and we need to highlight this in some way. 

I've seen other projects put community contributed modules under a `contrib` folder to make it clear to the community where the boundaries are.

Would you mind moving the `mesos_executor.py` file under `airflow/contrib/operators/`? Also add a note "(community contributed)", or "contributed by @kapil-malik" in the docs where you think it makes sense.
Make sense.

I've been bit with releases breaking their API (flask-login) recently.

It theory pre `1.0` release can break their API in second digit releases and post 1.0 in their first digit release, so I'm matching that.

So for now my approach is to allow for `>=` than what I run my unitests on, and `<` than where the API may change.

The alternative are:
- Fully pinning version numbers, missing out on bug fixes and security updates
- Using `>=` and hope for the best (and face the worst)
- ?

Airflow is special as it has a lot of dependencies by the nature of the project, so we will suffer from dependencies changing APIs. This is trying to prevent that.

BTW it's about time for pandas to go 1.0 ! Wow.
I trust pandas to not break the API until 1.0 btw, I'll approve a PR that says `<1.0.0`
`schedule_interval` is a DAG param now...

^ +1 to HttpPostThenSense. When dealing with REST APIs, the POST is often an async trigger, and I need to confirm whether the job completed successfully or failed / killed, by continuously sensing with a GET.
We've defined it as a Plugin operator, for our particular pattern of POST/GETs, but I believe a generic solution will be very helpful too. xcom is excellent for doing ad-hoc communication, but in this case it's more convenient to define and treat Post+Sense as a single operator.

http://celery.readthedocs.org/en/latest/userguide/optimizing.html#librabbitmq
subversion?

It shouldn't be an issue with `pip install airflow` because it's marked as optional. 

However, I echo that it shouldn't be a requirement for airflow. It's not even a hard requirement for celery (we use a redis backend for celery on python 3 -- `pip install celery[redis]`. Works great with airflow.)

We now support using environment variables to define connections.

Do you think the solution is to somehow disregard plugins when running `initdb`?
Also, what if your plugin would use a try statement to figure out that you are in a pre-init state and not do anything?

Maybe mysql-python is still needed for celery. But celery should also work with sqlalchemy and sqlalchemy works with pymysql (http://celery.readthedocs.org/en/latest/getting-started/brokers/sqlalchemy.html)

The way we typically do this is by clearing first either through the CLI or the UI (include downstream!), and then reprocessing, either by letting the scheduler pick up the tasks, or by running a backfill command which will only fill in the blanks (the tasks you just cleared)

The combination of `clear` and `backfill` allows to perform practically any surgery on a DAG in a few commands.
Seems resolved, closing.
I think [optional] celery requirements shouldn't block airflow at all, especially since celery is itself optional for airflow. See also #423
Yes I also use airflow with redis and celery and was only a bit confused why librabbitmq is in the dependencies
